greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest prime divisor of 4n^2+3 that is of the form 6k+1.
comment: Any prime divisor of 4n^2+3 different from 3 is congruent to 1 modulo 6.
4n^2+3 is never a power of 3 for n > 0; hence a prime divisor congruent to 1 modulo 6 always exists.
a(n) = 7 if and only if n is congruent to 1 or -1 modulo 7.
reference: D. M. Burton, Elementary Number Theory, McGraw-Hill, Sixth Edition (2007), p. 191.
link: N. Hobson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
N. Hobson, Home page (listed in lieu of email address)
example: The prime divisors of 4*3^2+3=39 are 3 and 13, so a(3) = 13.
results.author: Nick Hobson, Nov 26 2006
